vision.notes: Bee-eaters are visually oriented, using sight to locate flying insects. They have richly coloured plumage, suggesting a role for visual communication. Diurnal lifestyle suggests well-developed color vision.

hearing.notes: Auditory cues are likely important for communication within colonies and for detecting predators. Given their gregarious nature, vocalizations are expected.

taste.notes: Taste is likely used to assess the palatability of insect prey after venom discharge. Further specifics are unknown.

touch.notes: Tactile sense is important for manipulating prey, removing stingers, and building nests in burrows.

smell.notes: The role of olfaction in bee-eaters is currently unknown. Further research is needed.
